awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Reactive Nanobubbles Technology for Green and Sustainable Environmental and Agricultural Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to catalyze the development and commercialization of innovative nanobubble technologies in environmental, agricultural and other potential engineering applications. In environmental applications, reactive nanobubble technologies could impact water or wastewater treatment industries, municipal water treatment plants, drinking water disinfection, natural and landscape water management and remediation of impaired water bodies (e.g., by algal bloom). Value propositions include the improved water treatment efficiency (e.g., increased disinfection efficacy), reduced use of traditional hazardous chemicals such as chlorine, and reduced maintenance/operational cost in water remediation. In agricultural fields, irrigation with nanobubble water can significantly improve dissolved oxygen in water by 100-5000% and efficiently deliver oxygenated water and growth elements such as nitrogen to plant roots. Thus, the value propositions include improving crop or plant's growth, health and quality. Moreover, nanobubble water can positively affect turf and grass business and promote reduced or chemical-free fertilization in turf or lawn maintenance and therefore increase ecosystem safety and reduce negative environmental impacts.  

This I-Corps project explores fundamental engineering principles of colloidal bubble systems at nanoscale dimensions. Innovative scientific approaches employ reactive nanobubbles to control and mitigate water pollution as well as support smart agricultural irrigation/fertilization. Specifically, nanobubble technologies are processes that generate ultra-small sizes of bubbles with a diameter of < 1 um dispersed in water or other liquid media. Nanobubbles in water have a long residence time in water due to their low buoyancy and excellent stability against coalesces, collapse or burst, and the formation of bulk bubbles. Therefore, compared to regular bulk or large bubbles, nanobubbles have a higher efficiency of mass transfer due to their high surface areas, which also facilitates physical adsorption and chemical reactions in the gas-liquid interface. Therefore, nanobubble technologies are potentially useful in many industrial and engineering applications, ranging from ultra-sound imaging and intracellular drug delivery, pharmaceutical manufacturing, detergent-free surface cleaning, mining separation, water purification to wastewater treatment. This I-Corps project focuses on the evaluation of unique business models in water pollution control and mitigation as well as irrigation for agricultural applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
Nanobubbles (NBs), which are bubbles generally with a diameter of < 1 μm, hold promise in green and sustainable engineering applications in diverse fields (e.g., water/wastewater treatment, remediation, medical applications, and agriculture). NBs exhibit many intriguing properties such as long residence time, high mass transfer efficiency, and large specific surface area. Although there has been a growing number of commercial NB applications (e.g., water aeration), its potential market values and impacts in water purification, remediation, agricultural irrigation, and antimicrobial applications are not well studied and validated.

We have tested six specific hypotheses in the I-Corp project: (1) irrigation using NBs in water could trigger the grass growth by delivering nutrients and soil texture improvement, which reduces water usage and fertilizer use. (2) the use of ozonation NBs to replace chlorination or traditional ozonation could reduce the cost of water treatment or disinfection and also increase the effectiveness of disinfection. (3) the use of ozonation or oxygen NBs in dental rinsing could reduce periodontal diseases and reduce the use of antiseptics or antimicrobials that increases a global concern about antimicrobial resistance. (4) nanobubbles in water could reduce surface tension and increase the mobility of soil contaminants such as heavy metals, oil and organic compounds such as PAH, which may lead to greener soil remediation and cleaning processes (without the use of surfactants or other chemical rising solutions). (5) air or oxygen NBs can reduce algae-induced anoxia/hypoxia via boosting up aerobic microbial activity such that water quality in natural waters such lakes/ponds could be improved. (6) for swimming pools and other recreational water treatment, injection of NBs could reduce hazardous disinfectant chemical usage (free chlorine or copper sulphate), which may reduce the safety concerns and human health effects (e.g., skin irrigation from synthetic chemical exposure).

We conducted over 200 interviews with various industries and sectors (e.g., water treatment, agriculture, dental science, remediation) and identified many key barriers for commercialization of NBs in different applications, which are summarized below as part of the primary project’s outcome. Our go/no-go decision will depend on the application fields we examined (e.g., go for water or soil remediation and no-go for decentralized water treatment, disinfection and agricultural irrigation).  Specific learning points and intellectual merits include (1) understandings of colloidal stability mechanisms (e.g., aggregation or coalescence mechanisms and kinetics and radical formation) of different gaseous nanobubbles under environmentally relevant aqueous conditions. The applications of nanobubble applications as a green water solvents or additive may be limited by the colloidal and chemical properties such as natural decay due to pressure or temperature variations. The longevity of NBs in water or other liquid will be critical for delivery and storage in commercial product sale and activity of the claimed functions such as aeration and disinfection. (2) plant growth with irrigation of different nanobubble water could be synergistic in organic farming that regulates the use of chemical fertilizers. The enhanced nutrient absorption by plant roots and nutrient release from soil in the presence of nanobubbles could potentially reduce both water and fertilizer use. (3) ozone NBs could possibly remove biofilm and other pathogenic microbes without inducing antibiotics resistance. However, producing ozone NBs in a commercial process could be energy intensive and reduce economic viability of ozone NB processes. (4) oxygen NBs as aeration could increase the delivery time of dissolved oxygen and largely abate the water hypoxia. However, to remove water pollutants such as algal bloom, microbubbles or large bubbles are desirable as they can yield efficient air flotation.

This project engaged 3 Ph.D. students, two master students and several undergraduate students in the intensive business development training and customer discovery. This engagement also led to a few federal grant applications or spin-offs funding that further synergize their learning processes and laboratory research experiences. For instance, our students were involved in NSF PFI and INTERN grants/projects that allowed them to receive direct mentorship and internship from industrial mentors (e.g., 3M and Sterlitech) or hosts. Student members attended a number of national and regional conferences, symposiums and trade shows (e.g., AWWA and ACS) and received comments from diverse groups of audiences on nanobubble technologies and their market values. This I-Corp program also catalyzed the PI’s team to conduct one pilot demonstration of NBs in water and soil remediation in New Jersey, one NB technology patent application and continuing exploration of different value propositions in above mentioned fields.

 


Last Modified: 10/03/2021
Modified by: Wen Zhang
